segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 22
segments.en: Linked Discourses 22

segments.pli: 9. Theravagga
segments.en: 9. Senior Mendicants

segments.pli: 88. Assajisutta
segments.en: 88. With Assaji

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā assaji kassapakārāme viharati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
segments.en: Now at that time Venerable Assaji was staying in a monastery built by a Kassapa, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā assaji upaṭṭhāke āmantesi:
segments.en: Then he addressed his carers:

segments.pli: “etha tumhe, āvuso, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatha:
segments.en: “Please, reverends, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

segments.pli: ‘assaji, bhante, bhikkhu ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
segments.en: ‘Sir, the mendicant Assaji is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

segments.pli: So bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī’ti.
segments.en: He bows with his head to your feet.’

segments.pli: Evañca vadetha:
segments.en: And then say:

segments.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena assaji bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
segments.en: ‘Sir, please go to the mendicant Assaji out of compassion.’”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato assajissa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They did as he asked.

segments.pli: “assaji, bhante, bhikkhu ābādhiko … pe …
sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena assaji bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena.
segments.en: The Buddha consented in silence.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā assaji tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Venerable Assaji.

segments.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā assaji bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
segments.en: Venerable Assaji saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,

segments.pli: Disvāna mañcake samadhosi.
segments.en: and tried to rise on his cot.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ assajiṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: But the Buddha said to him,

segments.pli: “alaṃ, assaji, mā tvaṃ mañcake samadhosi.
segments.en: “It’s all right, Assaji, don’t get up.

segments.pli: Santimāni āsanāni paññattāni, tatthāhaṃ nisīdissāmī”ti.
segments.en: There are some seats spread out by others, I will sit there.”

segments.pli: Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane. Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ assajiṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: He sat on the seat spread out and said,

segments.pli: “kacci te, assaji, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ … pe … paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no abhikkamo”ti?
segments.en: “Assaji, I hope you’re keeping well; I hope you’re alright. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

segments.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ … pe … abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no paṭikkamo”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, I’m not all right, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing is evident, not its fading.”

segments.pli: “Kacci te, assaji, na kiñci kukkuccaṃ na koci vippaṭisāro”ti?
segments.en: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”

segments.pli: “Taggha me, bhante, anappakaṃ kukkuccaṃ anappako vippaṭisāro”ti.
segments.en: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”

segments.pli: “Kacci pana taṃ, assaji, attā sīlato na upavadatī”ti?
segments.en: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”

segments.pli: “Na kho maṃ, bhante, attā sīlato upavadatī”ti.
segments.en: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”

segments.pli: “No ce kira taṃ, assaji, attā sīlato upavadati, atha kiñca te kukkuccaṃ ko ca vippaṭisāro”ti?
segments.en: “In that case, Assaji, why do you have remorse and regret?”

segments.pli: “Pubbe khvāhaṃ, bhante, gelaññe passambhetvā passambhetvā kāyasaṅkhāre viharāmi, sohaṃ samādhiṃ nappaṭilabhāmi.
segments.en: “Sir, before my time of illness I meditated having completely stilled the physical process. But now I can’t get immersion.

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, taṃ samādhiṃ appaṭilabhato evaṃ hoti:
segments.en: Since I can’t get immersion, I think:

segments.pli: ‘no cassāhaṃ parihāyāmī’”ti.
segments.en: ‘May I not decline!’”

segments.pli: “Ye te, assaji, samaṇabrāhmaṇā samādhisārakā samādhisāmaññā tesaṃ taṃ samādhiṃ appaṭilabhataṃ evaṃ hoti:
segments.en: “Assaji, there are ascetics and brahmins for whom samādhi is the essence, equating immersion with the ascetic life. They think:

segments.pli: ‘no cassu mayaṃ parihāyāmā’ti.
segments.en: ‘May we not decline!’

segments.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, assaji,
segments.en: What do you think, Assaji?

segments.pli: rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: Is form permanent or impermanent?”

segments.pli: “Aniccaṃ, bhante” … pe …
segments.en: “Impermanent, sir.” …

segments.pli: viññāṇaṃ … pe …
segments.en: “Is consciousness permanent or impermanent?” …

segments.pli: “tasmātiha … pe …
segments.en: “So you should truly see …

segments.pli: evaṃ passaṃ … pe …
segments.en: Seeing this …

segments.pli: nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānātīti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’

segments.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā ‘aniccā’ti pajānāti. ‘Anajjhositā’ti pajānāti. ‘Anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.

segments.pli: Dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā ‘aniccā’ti pajānāti. ‘Anajjhositā’ti pajānāti. ‘Anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.

segments.pli: Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā ‘aniccā’ti pajānāti … pe … ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.

segments.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati;
segments.en: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.

segments.pli: dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati;
segments.en: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.

segments.pli: adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati.
segments.en: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.

segments.pli: So kāyapariyantikañce vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. Jīvitapariyantikañce vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: Feeling the end of the body approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’ Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’

segments.pli: ‘Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, assaji, telañca paṭicca, vaṭṭiñca paṭicca, telappadīpo jhāyeyya;
segments.en: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.

segments.pli: tasseva telassa ca vaṭṭiyā ca pariyādānā anāhāro nibbāyeyya.
segments.en: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to lack of fuel.

segments.pli: Evameva kho, assaji, bhikkhu kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. Jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: In the same way, feeling the end of the body approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’ Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’

segments.pli: ‘Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānātī”ti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’”

segments.pli: Chaṭṭhaṃ.

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha,…

suttaplex.blurb: Venerable Assaji is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, and learns that Assaji has difficulty maintaining his meditation. The Buddha encourages him to contemplate the impermanence of the aggregates.
